data.question: What are the three new reduced polyoxometalate-based hybrid compounds presented in the study?
What is the role of Ru(bpy) in the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) photocatalytic system for CO2 reduction?
data.answer: Ru(bpy) served as the center of reducing CO2.

data.question: How do the photocatalytic CO2RR performances of 1/Ru(bpy) and 2/Ru(bpy) compare to 3/Ru(bpy)?
data.answer: 1/Ru(bpy) and 2/Ru(bpy) exhibit promising photocatalytic CO2RR performance into CO, while 3/Ru(bpy) shows poor photocatalytic CO2RR activity.

data.question: What is the selectivity percentage of CO production for the 1/Ru(bpy) and 2/Ru(bpy) photocatalytic systems?
data.answer: The selectivity of CO production for 1/Ru(bpy) and 2/Ru(bpy) photocatalytic systems is 96.3% and 96.4%, respectively.

data.question: What is the role of {P4Mo6}-based POMs in the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) photocatalytic system?
data.answer: {P4Mo6}-based POMs act as the sites of oxidizing TEOA.

data.question: How does the modified cobalt cation on {P4Mo6} polyoxoanions affect the photocatalytic CO2RR?
data.answer: The modified cobalt cation on {P4Mo6} polyoxoanions can optimize the energy band structure of parent {P4Mo6}, which regulates the electron transfer pathway of the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) photocatalytic systems, thus achieving highly efficient photocatalytic CO2RR.

data.question: What is the yield of CO produced by the 1/Ru(bpy) photocatalytic system under 10 hours of visible-light irradiation?
data.answer: The yield of CO produced by the 1/Ru(bpy) photocatalytic system under 10 hours of visible-light irradiation is 322.7 nmol.

data.question: What is the proposed mechanism for the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) photocatalytic system in CO2 reduction?
data.answer: Under visible-light irradiation, electrons are excited from the valence band of compound 1 or 2 to its conduction band. The excited electrons of compound 1 or 2 can be further transferred to the CB of Ru(bpy), which then uses the photo-induced electrons to reduce CO2 to CO. The photo-induced holes on the VB of compound 1 or 2 could oxidize the sacrificial agent TEOA.

data.question: Is the photocatalytic CO2RR performance of the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) system tunable?
data.answer: Yes, the photocatalytic CO2RR performance of the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) system is tunable.

data.question: Does the photocatalytic system without Ru(bpy) show significant CO2 reduction activity?
data.answer: No, without Ru(bpy), the CO2 reduction activity of the photocatalytic system is greatly reduced.

data.question: Is TEOA indispensable in the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) photocatalytic system for CO2 reduction?
data.answer: Yes, TEOA is indispensable in the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) photocatalytic system for CO2 reduction.

data.question: Does the photocatalytic CO2RR activity of the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) system depend on the species of central metal in {M(P4Mo6)} clusters?
data.answer: Yes, the photocatalytic CO2RR activity of the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) system depends on the species of central metal in {M(P4Mo6)} clusters.

data.question: Can the photocatalytic CO2RR performance of the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) system be improved by optimizing the energy band structure of {P4Mo6}-based compounds?
data.answer: Yes, the photocatalytic CO2RR performance of the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) system can be improved by optimizing the energy band structure of {P4Mo6}-based compounds.

data.question: Is the photocatalytic CO2RR performance of the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) system affected by the presence of peripheral Co2+ ions on {Co(P4Mo6)}?
data.answer: No, the peripheral Co2+ ions on {Co(P4Mo6)} are not the active centers for CO2RR and their number has negligible influence on the photocatalytic activities.

data.question: Does the photocatalytic system {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) produce liquid phase products during CO2 reduction?
data.answer: No, no liquid phase product is detected in the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) photocatalytic system by ion chromatography during CO2 reduction.

data.question: Is the photocatalytic CO2RR performance of the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) system stable over time?
data.answer: Yes, there is only slight attenuation of the CO generation within 10 hours of light irradiation, indicating the photochemical stability of the {P4Mo6}/Ru(bpy) system.
